entry.title: second girlfriend, C2; post-breakup

About 6 weeks after the breakup we had a class together. After the class C2 came over to my house and I made pizza and ice cream. She didn't want to have sex, as she was still feeling angry. She said we might have sex after the anger was dissipated.
Earlier the same day I received my first blowjob from K1. I didn't tell C2 I was already dating and having sex with other people.

Two weeks later C2 spent the night -- she slept in a separate bed at my house. That weekend we went on a two day road trip. No sex due to a medical issue and she was on her period. I asked her what the status of our relationship was and she said it was "in limbo."

When I'm with C2, I eat more than I otherwise would. I do activities I would otherwise not do and enjoy them simply because I'm with C2.

entry.title: skillset of a hustler
entry.content:
A hustler's skill is in manipulating people to take specific actions.

To accomplish this requires both logic and either transfer of emotional state or evoking an emotional response. The reason for the emotional component is to address the halting problem. If you don't set the emotional bounds for your audience, logic and evidence may lead to different conclusions.

A hustler has a negative connotation because they are seen as manipulative. Here manipulative means the person is inducing certain emotional and logic process and they are not being vulnerable.

When both parties are vulnerable, then the emotional interaction is viewed as a good bond.

Being emotionally vulnerable means sharing the personal cause suffering.

entry.title: Revelation on sex from L1, quickly applied to outing with C4
entry.content:
L1 and I have been going out for 3 weeks, and the sex has been great. Our libidos are well matched. With so much sex, we haven't actually talked much. Saturday L1 decided it was time to go for a walk (after sex) and talk.

During the conversation, L1 asked, "Would you cheat on me?" I laughed and didn't immediately respond, and this (understandably) perturbed L1. They typical response would be an immediate and defensive "no" with no further discussion. Instead, I asked what she meant by cheating. From being with previous girlfriends, I knew I would continue to look at attractive women, even if I was with the hottest. We eventually negotiated that what we meant by "cheating" was sex, kissing, touching ass and touching genitals. Touching boobs is allowed, if it is one time (not on going).

The conversation continued; we gave a quick history of our relationships, with my latest being the last story. One of the reasons I broke up with C2 was because I wanted more sexual experience (so far K1 and L1). L1, not wanting that to be a reason I broke up with her, said I could have sex with other girls while we are in a relationship! There are (reasonable) conditions: I would notify L1 in advance, and proper protection against STI is required. This made me ecstatic, as I didn't want to give up a relationship with L1, and I didn't want to limit myself to three sexual experiences. With this permission, L1 allowed me to satisfy both goals.

The next day, Sunday, L1 left for vacation. I entertained myself by going to a yoga class with C4. On our previous date (before I met L1), C4 only wanted to talk -- no sex. I wasn't sure whether C4 thought our outing was social or a date, so I told her about my new relationship with L1 once we met up. C4 was disappointed, but continued on with our activities: yoga, meal, then a movie. After the meal, we were both stinky from the hot yoga class. We headed back to C4's place for a shower before the movie. I showered, then C4 said she wanted a massage and wasn't interested in going to a movie.

My situational awareness had been up all day with C4, and this was the transition point from social outing to attempted intimacy. I told C4 about my conversation with L1 the previous day, and that I would not be having sex with C4. I texted, then called L1 to let her know the situation with C4. By the time I had written out the text, I knew I didn't want to proceed with C4. I let L1 know to go back to her vacation and not worry.

C4 wanted to snuggle, which we did in her bed. As protection against progress, I left my shoes on and C4 wouldn't let me fully onto the bed (which was my intention). I did end up giving C4 a quick back massage, but it was a parting gift. I left C4 and drove home. I messaged L1 about the status.

entry.title: How I currently judge females, and the unhealthy categories
entry.content:
When I see a girl, I can characterize my instantaneous response into three categories of attraction:

  • Not attractive
  • Decent
  • Heart stopping 

There are three domains for these ratings: her body, her face, and her personality. A girls face is usually the quickest to judge because it's typically not covered. In winter it can be harder to judge a girl's body when covered in multiple layers; during yoga judgement is easier. Personality usually takes longest, as it depends on interaction.

While this isn't as granular as the conventional 1 to 10 numeric, there is some basis for the three categories. By "not attractive," what I mean is that I'd probably have sex with the girl, but it would be only once and I wouldn't want to be associated publicly with the girl. "Decent" implies that I'd want to have sex with the girl repeatedly, and it would be ok to be publicly associated with the girl. Lastly, by "heart stopping" I mean the girl is straight out of my fantasies. I have self doubt over whether I'm worthy of being associated with her.

None of what I describe above sounds healthy, either socially or for my own internal mental state.

entry.title: notes from socializing as an experiment
entry.content:
Last night I attended a social event. A happy hour is not my typical weeknight. It's undirected interaction.
Driving to the event, I realized I had no plan, no definition of success, and no enthusiasm. I felt a bit anxious, and that I was wasting my time on an activity I don't enjoy.

I wasn't worried about my own feeling of value. I had previously asked, "What value are other people to me?" I wasn't able to come up with a good answer for general interactions. The value I get from other people are information, pleasure, and the potential for pleasure.

I realized I could flip the question to be, "What value do I provide others?" This yielded a plan: to help others have a good time. My indicator of success: evoke a smile from one person.

Once at the event, I was able to quickly achieve this success.

Eye contact was relatively easy once I knew to focus on it. I was able to observe whether others made eye contact.

I like finding the odd balls

I didn't focus on attractiveness

I need to work on projection

I fell into the trap of technical conversation. I asked a person I was talking to about the app they were using for their hobby.

I focused on facts. A person I was talking to claimed that since she was from Ohio, she didn't have an accent. I didn't believe her, but I let it go. She brought it up again with another person, so I decided to look it up. I even spent the time to find a reputable source,
https://www4.uwm.edu/FLL/linguistics/dialect/staticmaps/state_OH.html
Confronting the person about being wrong didn't yield a positive emotional engagement for either party.

entry.title: advice on poly relationships for the first timer (me)
entry.content:
I asked my poly support group what advice they have for a person starting out with a third person in a relationship. There were about 50 people, and as many tips.

  • Talk talk talk. This was the main point, delivered over and over. Honest communication is paramount. Talk with your primary, talk with your secondary.
  • Talk with your primary before,  during,  after having a third person in the relationship
  • 2 people = 4 relationships, 3 people = 9 relationships (n people = n^2 relationships). For the 2 people, there is A --> B, B --> A, A --> A, and B --> B. This is why having multiple partners is more complicated
  • New relationship energy: puppy love, infatuation, etc all occur with a new partner. This can lead to neglect of your primary partner for a limited duration
  • Old relationship energy: your relationship with your primary is your foundation. You will come back to and more deeply appreciate this 
  • Pay attention to your own feelings
  • Repeatedly check status with your primary. The first answer isn't the final answer. Keep asking the same question until they tell you to stop
  • Discuss details of your interaction: feelings, actions. Be specific
  • Discuss with primary what level of detail they want to know -- everything, or just the bare minimum
  • What is your primary getting out of this?
  • This is fishing, not hunting
  • Check-in frequency can change on both your side and your primary's preference

Physical appearance of the people I want to interact with has some role for my ego. I don't understand how it pertains in my relations.
I realize my appearance matters because it impacts how other people judge me.

entry.title: vasectomy, one month after the surgery
entry.content:
It's been about 1 month since my vasectomy, and I'm happy. Happy that I have no pain, happy with the choice I made, and happy I won't be having kids. There is very little noticeable change in the appearance of my ball sack.

I've been doing vigorous exercise for the past two weeks (kickboxing, aerial yoga, etc) with no problems. Sex is the same as it was prior to the vasectomy, except now without the lingering worry of potential pregnancy. I continue to wear a condom and have not yet had unprotected vaginal sex.

I haven't had sex with any new partners, but I look forward to the reactions I'll get when I tell females I cannot have kids with them. Kids, or the potential for kids, seem to be an important factor to females for the age range I'm dating.

entry.title: A long first date: initial interaction with L1
entry.content:
I've had a profile on match.com for a while and have edited it to be both unique and compelling. L1 initially contacted me and we sent a few message back and forth over the course of a week. I've learned how to successfully communicate on e-dating websites (material for a separate post). We moved from match.com to texting.

I had been flirting with another girl and set up a first date to see a free screening of Back to the Future. This girl flaked the night before, so I contacted L1 to see if she was doing anything Thursday evening. She wasn't, so I invited her to the movie.

L1 was an hour late, but I didn't mind. Movies usually aren't good first dates since there's limited interaction, but it turns out Back to the Future is a romantic comedy. After the movie I walked L1 towards her car. We came to a bench on the sidewalk and she said we should sit and talk since we had not conversed due to the movie. We talked for a while. I eventually asked L1, "Can I ask you an awkward question?" (Yes.) "Can I kiss you?" (Yes). We made out for while on the bench, then talked some more. Before leaving I asked what her plans were for the weekend. She said she might be busy Saturday, but had two tickets for a movie near her house (30 minutes from mine). I invited myself to join her at the movies Friday night. We parted around 1am on Friday.

I met up with L1 at the theater near her house (she was late again, though only 10 minutes this time). The movie she had wanted to see was no longer playing, so we decided to walk around the mall. We shopped and I bought a few things. There was a free outdoor concert starting, so we decided to sit and listen. I lay on the grass and took off my shirt. We cuddled for the whole concert.

After the concert we were slightly hungry so we walked to a nearby steakhouse. I had an appetizer and she ordered an entree. L1 ordered three margaritas, which I interpreted as a good sign. We left at midnight, an hour after the steakhouse closed. L1 was getting pretty horny, so I said I'd take her to my place.

My house was under construction, but L1 didn't seem to mind. She came twice, I came and we went to sleep around 4am.

I was up Saturday at 8am and made some food. L1 got up and we did yoga, ate, shared a bath, and went shopping. More sex even though we were both tired from repeated sleep deprivation.

I dropped L1 off Sunday morning.

entry.title: mindset of interaction participants
entry.content:
When two people talk, each person has a mindset of {politeness, curiosity, attraction}, or some combination thereof.

Each participant may have a different mindset in an interaction: a person feeling attracted may be talking to someone who feels curiosity.

The respective mindsets change based on what is said (verbally, through body language, and through actions). A person may feel curiosity, then attracted, then politeness all in a single conversation.


I was at a party and made a mistake of not recognizing the mindset of a girl. I had started the process of getting ready to go. A girl started interacting with me, either out of curiosity or attraction. I was focused on grabbing my stuff and exiting, so I engaged with a politeness mindset. She was attractive, so reciprocating with either a curiosity or attracted mindset would have been appropriate.

entry.title: feelings and their role in a relationship
entry.content:
I'm a guy. I won't go so far as to claim "typical guy" but I share many of the common symptoms. I recognized that I didn't know what "feelings" and "emotions" were.

I'm now in my third intimate relationship [I'm now 31!].  During my second relationship, I figured out that "feelings" refer to physical responses to a situation. Symptoms include increased heart rate, constricted chest. "Emotions" are how these physical reactions effect thinking.

One of the reasons for this lack of development (no progress until about age 30) is that no one asked me about feelings in a meaningful way. Questions like, "How do you feel?" are effectively meaningless when I don't have the vocabulary. Most of the time I don't take the time to notice how by body feels in various situations.

Now I find that noticing my physical response can deepen the effect. My responses are often based on actions, i.e., sex.

entry.title: What is emotional chemistry in a relationship?
entry.content:
a definition of chemistry: you think of and desire someone when they are not present

alternative definition of chemistry (aka wavelength) = shared values, humor, communication, interests, goals,

method for determining chemistry: Show some emotion and see if the other person is attracted.

Emotions described verbally without words: "ahhh" to indicate relaxation, "mmm" to indicate interest. Inflection, rate, and duration matter.

emotional chemistry in a relationship also involves being sensual. Non-verbal communication, for example the eyes, touch (specifically caress), smell, are relevant.

Focus on sensual (physical sensation) rather than cerebral (thinking).
Do you blush? Can you find what makes the other person blush?
Do you smile? Can you find what makes the other person smile?
Do you laugh? Can you find what makes the other person laugh?



"Find a guy who calls you beautiful instead of hot, who calls you back when you hang up on him, who will lie under the stars and listen to your heartbeat, or will stay awake just to watch you sleepwait for the boy who kisses your forehead, who wants to show you off to the world when you are in sweats, who holds your hand in front of his friends, who thinks youre just as pretty without makeup on. One who is constantly reminding you of how much he cares and how lucky he is to have you.The one who turns to his friends and says, thats her.'"
Chuck Palahniuk

entry.title: vasectomy, day 1
entry.content:
Appointment 1: early February 2014
co-pay for visit: $30
met with nurse who took blood pressure, temperature, weight.
met with doctor who covered description of vasectomy procedure and potential complications, all of which I was familiar with based on my reading.
Pharmacist gave 1 valium. cost $5.10

Appointment 2: Friday morning, mid March 2014
Woke 6:30am. Ate breakfast with C2. We left the house 8:30am. I took my valium in the car at 9am. Checked in at clinic for 10am appointment. Waited until 9:30am, was called into office. Weight (182lbs with shoes), blood pressure, and temperature taken by nurse. Then I was led into an office with a bed. I undressed (left my shirt and socks on) and went to the bathroom. The nurse then shaved my scrotum with an electric trimmer.

She turned off the lights and left the room for about 30 minutes. I felt sleeping, probably the valium taking effect. The doctor came in around 10:10am and the nurse prepped by wiping my nuts with antiseptic. Then the doctor injected a numbing agent with a needle -- actually less painful than donating blood. During the procedure the nurse distracted me with conversation while the doctor concentrated on the operation. Took about 20 minutes per side. A piece of the vas deferens is sent to the lab to ensure the cut is of the correct tube. There was smoke from the cauterizer, but other than that I felt only minor discomfort. I could feel some tugging, but nothing terrible.

After the procedure was finished, a topical numbing agent was applied and the incisions were sewn shut. I was awake and communicative the whole time. I was very ginger getting off the bed and getting dressed. I wore baggy pants and loose boxers. I was given paperwork explaining the details of follow-up. Swelling and bruising are normal. Grapefruit size or puss are bad signs.

I walked out (wide legged stance) and called a cab to take me home. I was extra careful sitting in the cab -- very deliberate and slow movement. I got home and sat on a bag of frozen peas.

Following the two week resting period, I will need to ejaculate 20 or more times and wait 2 months. Then the semen is inspected to ensure zero sperm are present.

The incisions on both sides of my scrotum are small and the stitches are minor.


The weekend after the procedure I went on a roadtrip. I sat on ice part of the time. Instead of walking, I sat in a wheelchair. It was more discomfort rather than pain. There was a small urge to itch the stitches which I resisted.

entry.title: second girlfriend, C2. Part 1: initial courting
entry.content:
After the disastrous first episode with C1, I decided to focus on building a social life and not focus on dating. I built a semblance of a social calendar using meetup.com. I like a variety of events. I volunteered, did fun physical activities, and ended up with a group of aquantiences (not friends). One of the volunteering events I had done a few times was organizing books for a literary charity. After the work, we would go as a group to a nearby restaurant for lunch.

At one of these events I brought my parents, who were in town visiting. C2 was also there and talked with my parents. I didn't think anything of it at the time.

I volunteered at the same place again, talked with C2 after the lunch, and later sent a "Good to meet you" to C2 (part of the features on meetup.com). She interpreted this as a sign I liked her. She replied with an email, leading to her asking if I wanted to get together by suggesting a few options for activities.

We dated, finding a variety of activities through meetup. We went to dancing lessons, karaoke, and parties.

As of mid-November, no sex or even kisses, just hugs.


Analysis:
I still had no idea what I was doing; this was my second girlfriend. I didn't know what to expect or how to act. I simply did what I thought I would enjoy, hoping C2 would join me. I had no long term plans. It was simply, "what are we doing next together?"

I felt no urgency to have sex. She was not unattractive, but not what I would have otherwise been interested in. I had no motivation to talk to her, but it wasn't bad talking to her. I felt no lust; I was just happy to have a female to talk to one-on-one.

entry.title: match.com response rates
entry.content:
I previously posted about my messaging response rate from OKCupid. I recently joined match.com and can now compare the two dating services.

From Dec 26 to Dec 28 (2 days) I messaged 23 unique users and got replies from 3 unique users. It's too early to have a good ensemble, but that's 13%.

The incentives on match.com are a bit different -- for guys there's a minimum of messaging 5 unique users per month to get their guarantee.

Another distinction for match is that you get to see which messages that you've sent have been read.

entry.title: notes from sociologist studying poly
entry.content:
Source: 20 year longitudinal study
https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/the-polyamorists-next-door

Bias: participants in longitudinal study are more likely to be engaged in positive relationships

Typically experience is that poly evolves

Most people want multiple partners and want those partners to be exclusive to them

Advantages of consensual non monogamy
* Getting more needs met, primarily socially (emotionally) and sexually
* novelty
* stronger social support
* personal growth through addressing challenges
* poly effective relationships - deep emotional bond only ( similar to sibling bonding )
* responsibility diffusion

Disadvantages
* complexity of logistics, finances, emotional
* social stigma
* time used communication
* time spent introspecting, ie boundaries
* perception that poly means no boundaries
* more drama due to more people involved
* over use of veto power leading to resentment
* dislike of your partner's partner

Coming out lessons
* figure out why you want to come out to a specific person
* before coming out to family, make sure you are financially independent  (ie tuition, inheritance)
* choose an event where there's no pre existing emotional stress, limited audience, and focus isn't on someone else
* give time for the audience to react
* don't lead up with a negative (ie shameful) impression.
* poly is a choice you are making; it's not a reflection on the other person
* use a less sensitive topic to lead to the relevant topic
* not coming out can be a reasonable choice. The action can be delayed


Jealousy
* Jealousy isn't necessarily an indicator there's something wrong
* it's a relevant and reasonable emotion.
 It can be legitimate
* determine the source (often based on fear of loss)
* practice self soothing. How do you have fun?
* cultivate independence
* fear of loss of being special
* Jealousy can be over non-sexual aspects
* the responsibility of addressing Jealousy is with all parties involved. May benefit from counseling

Jealousy can be due to lack of  respect and attention

Jealousy can be due to your issues, the other person's behavior, or history

"If you cared, you'd be jealous"

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_listening

Kids care about stability

entry.title: A negotiated breakup: how I view our relationship after two years
entry.content:
I've been in a relationship with L1 for more than 2 years. During that entire time we've been in an open relationship. The motivation for having an open relationship is so that I can pursue my desire to have sex with other girls.

One significant reason L1 consented to this when we first met was because she had a similar experience with her first boyfriend. She was happy with her first boyfriend, but wanted to have other relationship and sexual experiences rather than simply commit to the first person she had been with. The way she and her first boyfriend handled this was that she broke up with him.

Rather than break up with me, L1 has participated in my exploration process. That has been an amazing and unusual experience. I've had relationships with other girls, though no actual sex.

I value my relationship with L1. She's my ideal physically -- a perfect body. She has a lot of positive energy (ie singing to the radio, enthusiasm). We both have high libidos. We value health and athleticism. The fact that L1 allows me to pursue other girls while maintaining a long term relationship is amazing. I desire a limited amount of interaction (ie only weekends, limited phone contact during the week), and L1 is willing to do this.

When we first met, I wanted to use the label "companions" to describe our relationship. L1 didn't accept that; she wanted the label of boyfriend and girlfriend. I consented to that. For L1, boyfriend and girlfriend as labels have emotional weight. The labels do not for me, though I am aware of their cultural connotation. My interest in using the "companion" label was intentionally to avoid the cultural weight of a significant investment.

Although there many positive aspects to my relationship with L1, there are some gaps. L1 has strong emotions for me, and I don't reciprocate. I rarely feel any emotions, so this isn't an issue with me that is specific to L1. Second, I've grown complacent with L1 -- I appreciate her, but my interactions are routine. We do new things, enjoy each other's company, discover new aspects of our relationship, and are growing, but we also fall into ruts. Third, I don't respect L1. I suspect that this lack of respect hinders development of emotional engagement on my part. Lack of respect is not specific to L1 -- I respect very few people. The people I do respect earn it based on how they think, how they communicate, and what they are doing with their life.

The above points are valid -- it is what I want from L1
Interestingly, what I didn't include in my wants: * to respect and value L1 * to develop an emotional bond with L1
What I'm looking for in a partner: I want to respect/cherish/admire/value that person The reason I respect a person currently is * brilliant * doing something unusual * passionate
How I want to view other people in general: with respect value them

entry.title: tips for good conversation
entry.content:
Pay attention to your surroundings (situational awareness). You can then comment on features of your environment.
Apply a sense of curiosity about your surroundings. This curiosity extends to the people around you and the stories they tell. People usually like to talk once someone (you) provide contextually-pertinent questions. Positive outcomes are (1) you learn more about the person and (2) you might learn something new.

Not all topics are conventionally acceptable in all situations. "Social calibration" is situational awareness applied to social relations

Stimulating conversation is about provoking an emotional response. One way to do this is to challenge the claims made by others. Problem solving is another.

Each conversation has a purpose whether you know what that purpose is or not. It is helpful to know why you are talking.

I enjoy making predictions about my environment and then testing them.

I am direct. This requires that I know what I want.

entry.title: I want to understand humans
entry.content:
My interest in other people is to learn how they think. Do this by listening to individuals talk vulnerably
The value of other people to me is I can learn from their choices, decision process, experiences

It's hard for me to build rapport with a person who has poor communication skills. By poor communication skills, I'm focusing on both listening and speaking.

As an example, unsolicited talking is typically not good.

entry.title: important questions to discuss with an intimate partner
entry.content:
Did your parents argue? About what? How has that impacted you and your relationships?

What is most exciting in our interaction?

If you could imagine a future source of conflict between us, what would it be?

How to you interact with money (savings, retirement, debt)?

What kind of baby clothes would you buy?

entry.title: reflection on where I am with respect to intimate relationships, 2016
entry.content:
What drives me
I have an (intellectual, perhaps cultural) expectation of sexual and intimate experience

My desire causes me to suffer. As a result I'm not content.
I intentionally neglected to address the issue for 20 years
I suspect I cannot satisfy the desire, nor would it be good to suppress

In addition to the desire, there is a time constraint. Third factor driving me is fear of becoming a neurotic old man

I suspect there are two potential outcomes:
  • I reach some end state called success 
  • I am always like this, though with decreasing capacity to act on my desire

There's a lot of evidence that the second is typical

Importance of appearance
Physical appearance matters to me for two reasons lust and my ego
Having a hot girlfriend strokes my ego, makes socializing easier, provides a source of reliable sex.

I have an acquaintance who is physically attractive to me, but that's the only value she has to me. I won't be having sex with her, so the only thing I can do is stare. I don't like the feeling of being the creeper.


What I don't know: pace
Once a girl shows any willingness to spend time with me, I don't know what pace for escalating towards sex is acceptable
Pace refers to the rate at which conventional order of operations is carried out - name, touch, kiss, grope, sex


What I find attractive 
  • Not wanting more than you have
  • Unconventional thinking and behavior 
  • Physical body, face

I want in a partner: sex, physical attraction, inspiring, value


On a trip out of the country I observed that
  • hot girls with the body type similar to my current girlfriend exist
  • there are many of them
  • applies to a range of ages

What I want in life
  • Happiness - different from contentment or pleasure. Happiness is having a genuine smile not derived from current situation 
  • Learning - topics that interest me,  ie how humans work. More specifically, how to get attractive women to want to have sex with me 
  • Local decrease of suffering - relationships that are genuine 
  • Global decrease of suffering 

Pleasure with attractive girls fits in both learning and happiness and local decrease of suffering

I am not struggling. Struggle = work hard in order to compensate for the risk of not achieving a goal.
My lack of struggle is because I don't know what success is for sex. I don't think it is a number.

Leveraging my social network
My circle of friends from Meetup are reliable adults, physically fit, financially stable, educated, mostly single, responsible, reliable. While these are all good, it's not what I desire.
My social circles (yoga, social meditation, meetup) have lots of attractive females. However, sex with any of them seems unlikely


How to proceed
I should try being in a relationship in which I take risk. This might evoke emotion
The risk is that I get hurt emotionally

Action to take: more effort with dating websites: Okcupid, Match, Craigslist  

Bars and clubs don't leverage my strengths.
I don't like to dance, drink, or be subjected to loud music
Additionally, the people who frequent bars and clubs are not who I'm seeking

entry.title: reflections on what I've observed in my polyamorory experience
entry.content:
Monogamous people participate in poly, they just don't call it that. A mother loves her husband and her son and her daughter.

Poly discussion groups are biased towards people who like to talk.
It can be difficult to provide value for each participant due to the complexity of interactions and varying degrees of experience and education

Acting single in the world of dating feels disingenuous

I am unable to manage a vee relationship. A triad seems more reasonable
Vee can be either balanced (A and B are equals) or imbalanced (A has higher priority than B)
From an ethics perspective,

  • A knows of B, B knows of A
  • A doesn't know of B, B knows of A 
  • A doesn't know of B, B doesn't know of A
  • A knows of B, B doesn't know of A

I am only comfortable with the first situation

entry.title: second girlfriend, C2; second breakup
entry.content:
Last Sunday (a week ago) C2 emailed me recent test results showing she had a sexually transmitted infection (STI). She suspects she got the infection about 16 years ago. We had been having sex since November, and as recently as a few days prior to this notice (total time of 5 months). Here "sex" means both protected vaginal sex and unprotected oral sex.

This was emotionally devastating to me on multiple levels. One reason I hadn't sought sex until I was in my thirties was because I disliked the thought of getting STIs since middle school. I had been tested for STIs and come up negative, as had C2. I had been tested for Chlamydia, Gonorrhoeae, Syphilis, Hepatitis B, and Hepatitis C. It turns out Herpes 1 and 2 isn't normally tested for by my health care provider (neither is HIV).

Another reason for my distress was that after this first breakup with C2 I had sex with another girl, K1. Again, protected vaginal sex and unprotected oral sex. I let K2 know about my potential exposure within a few hours of the notice from C2. Neither I nor K1 showed symptoms of Herpes, but we both got tested the quickly (Tuesday). Neither K1 nor I have received test results yet.

I spoke with K1 Friday and she was angry at me but still able to talk with me. K1 wanted to know if we would continue to be friends and I said yes. K1 still wants to be with me, but I don't enjoy being with her.

C2 claims she was in denial about the Herpes-2 infection since the relationship in which she got it was drama-filled, albeit 16 years ago. The test results she sent me were from Wednesday, a few days prior to her telling me. I have no idea with C2 communicated this issue to previous sex partners. It's not clear to me whether C2 will tell future sex partners.

Yesterday I went with C2 to an event. We discussed our revelations from the past week. I told C2 I had figured out what made me happy with her: sex. Thus, her having an STI has two outcomes: either I test positive for Herpes-2 and continue to have sex with her, or I test negative and do not have sex with her. I am unwilling to continue to expose myself to the potential for infection. I enjoy being friends with her, but not to the degree if exclusivity that she desired.

Late yesterday C2 sent me an email explaining what I was willing to provide (friendship, sex) were not sufficient for her. She's effectively looking for the American Dream of stable husband, raising kids, etc. I'm not willing to compromise on these issues. She says remaining friends causes her too much emotional harm, so she will try to stop seeing me.

This indicates to me a failure of my negotiation skills. I have something she desires (sex, company), and she can provide what I'm looking for (sex, company), yet she doesn't want to be together.

My guess is that I don't have Herpes-2 (I show no symptoms), so this lack of C2 in my future isn't the end of the world. I will continue to look for attractive female friends, some of whom may become sex partners. If I test negative I'll be happy, but either way I'll be more vigilant about getting tested for all STIs, and requiring full STI results from potential sex partners.


I spoke with my sister about this topic and we agreed there is insufficient discussion about STIs in the United States. It's not part of the cultural norm to raise this topic, and it makes people uncomfortable. I've yet to see a popular romance movie or book which includes STIs or even testing for STIs.

I had previously found people that I respect, people that I valued, people who were badasses, and hot girls. This girl is all of this. And she wants to interact with me. This caused me to to experience the difference between a girl that is hot and a girl that his beautiful. The flood and variety of positive emotions is immense. Anxiety of "What if I fuck this up?" mixed with the excitement of, "She wants to interact with me?!"
The physical manifestation of the anxiety is "stomach flip-flopping" rather than a knot in the stomach.

Figuring out what causes this reaction would be useful, because then I would know what to seek in future interactions with other people.

**********

Her thinking is vulnerable and unconventional.
She's intellectually curious and interested in exploring emotional aspects.
She is a badass. Non-standard experiences.
She's a superb communicator.
introspective

I want to disrupt her expectations while ensuring she feels safe and secure.

If I ask an unconventional question to someone, there response options are

  • feel uncomfortable and not willing to engage
  • talk at length and not say anything of personal value. The confusing part is that the words they use have meaning, but not as strung together

entry.title: selection bias in dating choices
entry.content:
I first realized this selection bias when I started using OKCupid. The people on OKCupid are there for a few potential reasons
  • too busy to find potential mates in real life
  • insufficiently social to have a choice of mates
  • sufficiently physically unattractive that no one desires them
  • not socially assertive
  • criterion for mate are too selective or are self-contradictory
None of these are positive reasons to be on an online dating site. The attractive, functionally normal people have less difficulty in finding potential mates in real life because they are attractive and functionally normal.

There are two results of this selection bias. First, it is hard to find attractive, functionally normal people on online dating websites. Second, the fact that I'm using an online dating service means I'm not attractive and functionally normal.

People with larger and stronger social networks have an easier time both directly and through friends.  Online dating indicates smaller and weaker social networks
It's not just the number of people you are exposed to.  The people you hang out with are likely to be more compatible before you even meet

A way to counteract this bias is to grow your social network. More social activities with more people.  Meaningful relationships which cross social sphere boundaries

Solo meditation,  video gaming do not build healthy relationships. Further,  video games are mostly shooting or racing.  These aren't just time syncs, they're anti social.
No social training

entry.title: respecting others and finding value in others
entry.content:
Observation: In order to form emotional bonds with another person, it may be helpful to respect and value the person.
Claim: respect and value can be an individual basis, or all humans in general, or all living creatures.



I do respect a few people. The traits that cause me to feel this are brilliant, communicate effectively, are passionate, and are doing something unusual with their life.

I surveyed a couple friends to understand why they respect other people. Two responses I got:

  • Value people because each person has some wisdom based on their life experience
  • Value people because they have some aspect of me in them

Another response was more nuanced: Respect differences in others. Separately, each person has potential value, even if unrealized.

entry.title: my jargon for dating and relationship
entry.content:
Caveat
I'm a male, so these are with regards to females



stranger: a person you haven't met.

acquaintance: a person you have met but haven't become familiar with. You may know them by sight or even name, but you don't know much about them outside the role you interact with them.

friend: a person you know in multiple social roles. You have interacted sufficiently to know about them

good friend: a person you can call if you have a flat tire and need help

girl friend: For a male, you are not sleeping with this person but would if given the chance

companion: For a male, this is a girl with whom you are friends and you have sex with

girlfriend: For a male, this is a girl you are exclusively and explicitly committed to

spouse: Long term exclusive contractual agreement

love:

  • trust that I can be vulnerable with you
  • long-term reliability
  • long-term happiness
  • enjoying you as a whole person. Accepting your faults and your positive aspects.

entry.title: direct versus indirect communication
entry.content:
I was previously very goal oriented -- set a big goal, break it into small goals, develop plans to accomplish the series of small goals. Recently I've changed my way of thinking to use intentions rather than goals. Another way of phrasing this shift is having a direction, rather than a destination.

I generally think of my communication style as direct (others may say blunt). This is probably based on my lack of caring what others think, aka empathy. Directness in communication is well suited for being goal oriented, and I disdained indirect communication -- chatting, small talk, and other "meaningless" conversation. Either you had a goal and were moving towards it, or you are wasting your (and my) time.

With the change in thinking in terms of goals to now having intention, there is a corresponding change in how I value different communication styles.

Some topics I categorize as indirect have value, even if that value is initially unknown. Examples of this would be, "Did you sleep well?" This question can yield information on the person's level of irritability and can help explain future actions and decisions. Similarly, "How are you feeling today?" can be used to predict how that person interacts.

Other topics in a similar vein are past life experiences, future plans, likes, dislikes. Seemingly simple, useless questions like, "Where are you from?" and "How is your family?" can be emotionally relevant, as these factors affect the person's well-being.

When posing these questions, use reciprocal disclosure to increase relationship strength. This reciprocal disclosure of shared intimacy (decreasing privacy) builds trust.

entry.title: RE: Why are there so many male nudists?
entry.content:
Reposted from a forum:

A combination of many things, some more relevant in the past, some more so now. In no particular order:

1. Women's body shame: evil. From the Adam and Eve story on, women's bodies have been seen as something tempting, magical, and needing control.

2. Women's body shame: imperfection. Images of beautiful women, in art and advertising, set a standard a real body can seldom meet. This has begun happening to men only in the past few decades, and still affects women much more strongly.

3. Safety. If a woman is harassed or worse, bad enough, and if she "must have done something" to bring it on, she gets not even moral support in most quarters. And women are vastly more likely to be harassed and assaulted than men.

4. Men's visual sexuality: Nudity matters more to men; even genuinely nonsexual nudity creates a bit of libidinal buzz for guys that it just doesn't, for women.

5. Internet unreality / voyeurism: When men's genuinely nonsexual nudity isn't so nonsexual, after all.

6. Male shared experience: Within the lifetimes of older nudists, men were encouraged, even required, to share collective nudity in  sport and the military.

7. Women "giving it away": A revealing of the female body can be used as a bargaining chip, and when offered unrestrictedly, can be attacked, by women, as what is essentially unfair competition. And nudity, once familiar, ceases to be sexy, and that can be experienced as a loss.

8. Menstruation: Starting at the same time other body-shame issues begin to arise, and generally managed with covering up, complicates female nudity.

9. The gender-imbalance death spiral: An open nudist community will tend to start with more men, for the reasons above; most of those people will be heterosexual, and the arithmetic (let alone numbers 3, 4, and 5 above) dictates that the women will be under a certain degree of pressure, which many will find unwelcome. This reduces the number of women, which in turn exacerbates the problem.

entry.title: deciding between two choices indicates incomplete analysis
entry.content:
There are two general categories of causes for mistakes: mistakes by commission, and mistakes by omission. Mistakes by commission are when a decision maker makes a choice, but it turns out to be wrong. Mistakes by omission are when a decision maker fails by not making a decision.

Errors by commission are due to not enough information about the choices, incomplete set of choices presented, misinterpreting the available information regarding the choices. A decision maker cannot possibly gather all the information, nor present all options, and is fallible.

Typically I see the need for a decision, come up with two options, then decide between the two options. This causes mistakes by commission.

I can think of the following motivations for coming up with only two choices (rather than more). Two is the lowest number of choices I can come up  with before making a decision. That means it's both the least amount of work (thinking, research), and takes the least amount of time. Comparing two choices is easier than comparing three or more choices. With two choices, it's easy to categorize one of the options as "bad" and the other "good."

entry.title: emotional reasoning (as contrasted with standard logical reasoning)
entry.content:
I typically regard myself as a reasonably logical thinker. Then I learned that in order to make the correct decision it would require gathering all the information. Since this isn't practical, humans use emotions to determine when the information gathering should terminate and a decision rendered (see the halting problem). Thus, even people who claim to make purely logical decisions use emotions to make decisions. 

The amount of standard logic used to make decisions from person to person. For the purposes of this post, I'll simplify to two extremes -- logical thinking and emotional thinking. People who apply less standard logic use more emotional reasoning. If emotional reasoning doesn't use logic, then what is the mechanism or process?

Logical versus emotion

Typically logic is applied as a universal condition. For any situation A, take action B. There is the possibility for contingency, and it would be of the form, "For any situation A, take action B unless K occurred before A, then take action C." In contrast, emotional reasoning can be situationally dependent. "In situation A today I'm going to take action D, but if A had occurred last week I would have done F."

Certain situations evoke biological responses, ie being surprised by a sudden change in the local environment. A logical response when this surprise occurs again is, "Last time when X happened, it was followed by Y, so this time I'll.." In contrast, an emotional response goes like, Last time when X happened, I felt Z, so this time I feel..." Emotional reasoning relates the current situation to previous situations which induced emotional responses.

Conclusions

The reason this alternative method of thinking matters is because many people use it. For example, when a parent runs out of logical arguments with their children, they have to resort to emotional reasoning.

entry.title: How to flirt

Preview of content: flirting is essentially social skills + intent (and not goals).

Two general points

  • social calibration matters -- situational awareness applied to relationships, emotions
  • honesty about who you are, aka authenticity, matters

You should be confident in social interactions. How to be confident:

  • appearance is relevant, both in how people judge you and how you feel about yourself
  • be direct but playful
  • move on from mistakes.  Find humor in your mistakes
  • posture is important for both how others see you and how you feel about yourself
  • exercise. This will help you know your limits
  • masturbate. This will help you know your preferences 
  • speak slower. This is interpreted as confidence
  • be interesting -- you need to be able to explain to other people why you are interesting. What is your personal narrative?
  • fake it until you make it (i.e., upon first interaction). Once you're past the initial interaction, switch to being authentic

Every interaction has a goal. For example, you goal may be

  • kiss
  • sex
  • kids
  • companionship
  • dinner

Problem with having a goal: expectations might be unmet.
Solution: Remove the big goals and focus on smaller, more realistic outcomes
--> Broaden your definition of intimacy and success
For example, small steps (micro goals) include

  • eye contact
  • have a conversation
  • give an authentic compliment
  • invite the person to an activity
There are two types of complements: "drive-by" and "conversation opener." 
A conversation-opener complement prompts a response, whereas a drive-by does not.
Example of drive-by complement: "Nice beard."
Example of conversation opener: "Nice beard. How long have you grown it?"


There are three approach styles (bashful, budding, bold), distinguished by level of social aggressiveness. No style is better than the other two. Which fits you depends on your personality -- be authentic.

Approach style: "bashful"
For this style, ways of causing interaction include

  • give a drive-by complement
  • ask for help, ask for resources, ask for their preference
  • be helpful -- offer assistance
  • eye contact. If this doesn't come naturally, use "triangle gaze": look at the middle of their forehead, then switch to the edges of their mouth on both sides. Keep your gaze rotating among these three points on their face (rather than an intent stare of locking eyes).

Remember to focus on interaction,  not outcome
pro-tip: "flirting face." Use the body language, spatial distance, and facial motions of the reaction you have when you wonder, "Do I recognize that person?"

Approach style: "budding"
For this style, ways of causing interaction include

  • compliment which require response
  • buy small token gift (i.e., coffee)
  • practice reciprocal disclosure (answer, followed by question)

Approach style: "Bold"
For this style, ways of causing interaction include

  • directly admit attraction
  • in order to avoid being creepy, run your ideas for interaction past third parties
  • lead with awkward. Identify why you feel awkward, then talk about that with the target


Rejection by the other person is them rejecting the moment, not of you (remember, they don't know you)
To avoid dwelling on rejection, stay busy in your life
Don't overly focus on one target (even if you're married). You need strong social network
Set aside time for platonic relationships
Don't date to fill a void.
Go on a date by yourself

Social scripts for interaction displaces authentic intent.
Summary of Pervocracy blog post:
There are scripts for sex, such as

  • Consent roulette script
  • Robot lawyers script for consent
  • small steps, with enthusiastic response.  Reciprocal response (answer, question)

After class was over, I still didn't know what flirting was, so I asked the instructor. She said to recall that I should set an intention, not have a goal. That's what flirting is about.
Have a direction, not destination.

entry.title: hosting a great meetup event
entry.content:
Where to have an event:
Meeting in public spaces yields better turnout -- participants are taking less risk.

What to include in the event description
  • Specify where are you all are meeting
  • Specify how long the event is
  • Biographical background on the host. Specify that you are hosting the event, and provide credentials as to your qualifications as a host (relevant to that event)
  • If the event is an activity, are you meeting for drinks or dinner after?
  • What should participants bring?
  • How much will participants spend?
  • If carpooling, participants should split the gas cost with their driver
  • If a waiver is required, make the waiver available in the event description
Timing:
  • Plan an event and post the description 2 or 3 weeks in advance
  • Participants will show up about 15 minutes late
What to expect for RSVPs:
There's a threshold for sign up. No one signs up until everyone signs up.

Actual attendance:
The better you know potential participants, the more likely they are to show up

entry.title: My girlfriend of two+ years broke up with me
entry.content:
After more than 2 years in a relationship, L1 broke up with me on Friday, December 2, 2016. After breaking up we then went to a party in the evening, and another on Saturday afternoon. This was what I was seeking in a breakup -- that we remain friends and actually do stuff together.

We still have a strong component of lust. We are both horny and physically attracted to each other. We enjoy each other's company for short durations.

L1 has strong emotional feelings and I am not reciprocating. I'd like to, but I don't feel any emotional bond. The cause of this is probably that I don't respect or value L1.

The reason I respect people is because they are good communicators, passionate about something, doing something unusual with their lives, and are brilliant. L1 has none of these aspects.
The reason I value someone is because they have experience or knowledge that I could benefit from. L1 does not.
The reason I think someone is a badass is because they have unusual life experiences that have shaped their perspective. L1 has not had this.

I don't think it's reasonable for L1 to try and qualify for any one of these definitions. Thus choices include (me changing my definitions) and (me finding someone else who does qualify).

entry.title: emotion and touch
entry.content:
I form emotional bonds based on physical touch.

I want touch and emotional bond with people I find attractive.
I don't seek touch or emotional bond with people I do not find attractive.

Emotional bond implies I am, in a limited sense, beholden to that person.

In order to feel the sense of being beholden is worth investment, I want to be getting something of value. Here value is the possibility of interaction with people I find attractive.

entry.title: lessons learned from interacting with my girlfriend
entry.content:
Auto correct to the wrong spelling for a name is bad. Solution: remove incorrect spelling from autocomplete dictionary

Voice dictation of a name can yield the wrong spelling of a name

Unnecessarily complex sentence structure can result in unintended interpretations. Solution: use simple sentence structure

I made an assumption about my girlfriend, then stated it as fact to her. The assumption was incorrect, and she felt bad that I had misunderstood. Solution: identify my assumption, then form it as a question to her.

entry.title: Aspects of emotional development I need to work on
entry.content:
"Love all beings" is not consistent with my definition of respect
Respect = because the person is brilliant, communicates well, is passionate, and doing something unusual with their life
Love = a physiological sensation in my chest

How should I handle love and my feelings of lust? Can love and lust be concurrent?
Lust has multiple sources:

  • private validation of my ego
  • public validation of my ego
  • desire for physical pleasure


I want emotion without attachment.

Patterns lead to expectations. Desire for decreased risk.

I've been using YouTube videos to provide emotional stimulus. Music videos, short clips from TV and movies. These provide enough stimulation of the type I want and the duration I'm seeking.

I've been using Facebook to provide social stimulus; again when and how I want.

entry.title: I am willing to sacrifice for extremely hot girls
entry.content:
I attended a fancy reception in an expensive hotel where the host had hired a group of very attractive models to serve as greeters. After the reception I felt frustrated. I don't typically encounter girls that hot in my social circles, and the evening presented proof that they exist.

Dating apps (ie Tinder, Coffee Meets Bagel) and online dating (ie OKCupid) doesn't have many girls of this level of hotness. That's reasonable, as these girls would have no problem getting plenty of interest in real life.

entry.title: Craigslist m4w scammers
entry.content:
I posted the following in "m4w" (men looking for women) on craigslist.

Hey all you humans. Don't reply to this post. I'm seeking scammer replies so I can train my filter. I'm seeking automated replies, people who don't read posts, etc.

 If you find this humorous, feel free to chortle. If you want to collaborate or share tips, put the subject, "I may be a data scientist" in the subject line. If you are a female and want to talk with a guy who treats dating and casual encounters as a data processing challenge, reply with the subject, "I find intelligence attractive" in the subject line.

In the first 9 hours, I got 64 replies. I received no replies with either of the two suggested subjects.

entry.title: My motivation for dating has significantly changed
entry.content:
From the time I started dating (about 31 years old) until a few weeks ago, I dated girls to have sex with them. I was drawn to girls with a specific physical body type. I sought someone who is compatible, but I had little insight as to what that meant in practice. Shared values mattered, but I didn't know what that was in practice.

In the past few weeks I've felt intense emotions different than any other attraction I've experienced. Butterflies in my stomach distinct from anxiety. A rush of longing when the person isn't present. A desire to spend all my time with this person (prioritizing them above all else).

entry.title: I am socializing less
entry.content:
In the past year or two, I've observed that I socialize less than I used to.

A major factor is that I have relationship with a partner. Because I spend time with my girlfriend, I have less motive to socialize with other people.

The fewer interactions I have with people, the less disappointed I am in both myself and others.

entry.title: pro-tips in dating
entry.content:
Dating apps

  • distinguish yourself. Pictures of you in a suit is typical. You with a hunting accomplishment is likely a turn-off.
  • if she has a picture of a pet-like animal, ask her about it. She likely has a strong positive emotional state associated with the animal, or at minimum a story to tell
  • interaction should lead to more interaction - say something, then ask a question that is open-ended.


"You're not physically attractive" is not a positive statement.

How to flirt

  • whisper to her. This conveys that you are speaking only to her, and sharing the message is risky.
  • make her grin
  • make her blush

entry.title: Truth and communication
entry.content:
A friend came to me for help, and I offered her the help she sought. Once the time came to specify the logistics of the help, there was disagreement about what had been agreed to. 

When I say something to someone else, I try to be honest -- I mean what I say.

What the she interpreted what I had said, she used her definition of the words heard. The truth became what the she understood. 

Once disagreement based on perceived dishonesty occurs, recovery of trust is difficult.

entry.title: date within your own species
entry.content:
The advice of "date within your own species" was given to me when I realized I wasn't monogamous. I recognized what was meant -- that dating monogamous people wasn't going to yield success -- but I also knew that I would need to learn that lesson myself.

I've gone on first dates with monogamous girls. In an effort to be up front, I tell them that during our first in-person meeting.
